questions.question_text: A systems administrator observes high latency values when reaching a remote web server. Which of the following commands will help determine and isolate issues on the network side?

discussion.content: Network latency can be tested using Ping, Traceroute, or MTR. These tools can be used to determine specific latencies. While ping can be used to determine if a particular IP is reachable, the traceroute command can track the path that packets take to reach the host. It shows you how many hops it takes to reach the host and how long it takes between each hop. This allows you to diagnose possible bottlenecks in the network. MTR (also known as My Traceroute) is essentially a combination of Ping and Traceroute and is the most detailed.

Selected Answer: A
A: valid because "my trace route" shows statistics of latency
B: not valid because is for DNS queries
C: not valid because uses services/ports
D: not valid because is just for the routing table in private networks.

Selected Answer: A
A is the valid answer.

questions.question_text: A Linux administrator wants to obtain a list of files and subdirectories in the /etc directory that contain the word `services`. Once the files and subdirectories are discovered, they should be listed alphabetically in the /var/tmp/foundservices file. Which of the following shell scripts will accomplish this task?

A Linux administrator must identify a user with high disk usage. The administrator runs the # du `"s /home/* command and gets the following output:
//IMG//

Based on the output, User3 has the largest amount of disk space used. To clean up the file space, the administrator needs to find out more information about the specific files that are using the most disk space.
Which of the following commands will accomplish this task?

discussion.content:
Definitely B.

"-a, --all write counts for all files, not just directories"

-s will give you a summary.

https://www.redhat.com/sysadmin/du-command-options

Although in a 'real world scenario', B would be the ideal choice, the question is asking for "information about the specific files that are using the most disk space". For that reason, I would chose C. The -sh would gives you the total of sum of each file in human readable form.

Again, not necessarily what a person would do in real life. However, I see it as the "Exam Answer" and not necessarily as the "Real World Scenario" answer
B is the correct answer that to list out all the files' size in /home/User3 while C only display the entire summary used space.

it should be B. the "a" flag gives you info on all files, not just directories. C is wrong because the "s" flag is a summary and the "h" flag is a help flag. the /home/User/ directory doesn't make sense either

comments.content: I agree B is correct but the -h option is for "human-readable" - Not "help"

discussion.content:
wonder if anyone actually reads the link...
assuming that C contains a typo and is actually User3 and it's still wrong
du -sh /home/User3/ is going to print the exact same thing as du -h /home/* but just for user 3 and in human friendly format so....133M or something
du -a /home/User3/ on the other hand is going to print the size of every file so you can sort them by size and decide what to delete....
Do you thin the ""s may actually be -s to for summary of the du command?

questions.question_text: A systems administrator is enabling quotas on the /home directory of a Linux server. The administrator makes the appropriate edits to the /etc/fstab file and attempts to issue the commands to enable quotas on the desired directory. However, the administrator receives an error message stating the filesystem does not support quotas. Which of the following commands should the administrator perform to proceed?

discussion.content:
A is correct answer definitely 
After enabling quotas, the second step should be remounting file system
Issue the mount -o remount <file-system> command (where <file-system> is the name of the file system) to remount the file system. For example, to remount the /home file system, the command to issue is mount -o remount /home.
See reference https://access.redhat.com/documentation/en-us/red_hat_enterprise_linux/5/html/deployment_guide/ch-disk-quotas
B is not accurate as it only creates group quota file, missing user quota file

Selected Answer: A
A: valid, as explained here: https://access.redhat.com/documentation/en-us/red_hat_enterprise_linux/4/html/system_administration_guide/implementing_disk_quotas
B: (?)
C: wrong because edquota should be used on username not on directories
D: wrong because in this way the right command should be something like "quotaon -a" to mount automatically non-NFS filesystems in /etc/fstab ; or use "# quotaon -vug /home" command to manipulate user and group quota. I suppose.

I agree remounting filesystem is second step in setting quotas according to this link https://access.redhat.com/documentation/en-us/red_hat_enterprise_linux/4/html/system_administration_guide/implementing_disk_quotas

comments.content:
Pay attention to the question:
The administrator issue the commands to enable quotas on the desired directory. However, the administrator receives an error message stating the filesystem does not support quotas. So, he already tried 'quotaon' and it did not work.
Why? It has already been done after fstab is finished. Administrator must enable the filesystem now with answer D. I think provided answer is correct.

discussion.content:
C. modinfo, insmod, dmesg
modinfo – extracts information from the Linux Kernel modules given on the command line. If the module name is not a filename, then the /lib/modules/version directory is searched,

insmod – install module

dmesg – kernel log messages

https://vceguide.com/which-of-the-following-describes-the-order-of-commands-required-to-obtain-module-information-install-the-module-and-check-the-log-for-any-errors-during-module-installation/

Selected Answer: C
Shit yeah... the correct answer should be C.

lsmod----> show the status of modules in the Linux Kernel
modinfo ---> show information about a Linux Kernel module
insmod ----> simple program to insert a module into the Linux Kernel
modprobe ----> add and remove modules from the Linux Kernel

questions.question_text: A systems administrator needs to install a new piece of hardware that requires a new driver. The driver should be manually installed. Which of the following describes the order of commands required to obtain module information, install the module, and check the log for any errors during module installation?
